projects.title: Adapt Translations
projects.subtitle: a course project for CS32 Software Engineering - Spring 2017
projects.description: A web app that enables translators to align their original and translated documents for a seamless translation experience.

children.text: Our four-person team started the creation process by reaching out to faculty and students in the Comparative Literature department. By surveying them about their current translation-related behaviors, we learned that most just open two separate windows for their two documents, as well as other windows for online translation resources, but wish they had a better workflow.
portfolio/adapt/adapt-translations-2.gif
We decided to create a visual application that would display how two documents aligned without the user having to manually remember or find these links between documents.
As the only person on the team with front-end experience, I became the lead front-end developer on the project. Here are some of the most interesting features of the front-end that I implemented:
Optional matched scrolling through the two documents; scroll on one side and scroll proportionately through the other
Load documents from files, save and reload old projects
Inegration with the popular TinyMCE text editor for a familiar interface
Integration with Google Open Authentication for user accounts

projects.title: Uno Port Art Films
projects.subtitle: a site for a summer outdoor film festival in Japan
projects.description: Built on WordPress for future upkeep, I configured this new site on a short timeline to fit the needs of the festival. The key technical aspect of this new site was a new taxonomy system for organizing exisiting data and data types specific to the film festival.

children.text: This site transformed from a data dump of all of the past films shown to a navigateable site with descriptions, summaries, and help text.

projects.title: This site, 2.0
projects.subtitle: a React site built with curiosity
projects.description: After finishing my time at R/GA where I learned and used React for the first time, I rebuilt this site so I could have experience building with React from the bottom up. Enjoy!

children.text: This new website is a culmination of my time at R/GA in more ways than one. In addition to the new technical aspects of the site, I set my new focus for the site to be curation, as we had practiced in pitches during the apprenticship.

Where the old site had contained everything there was to know about me-- my hobbies, my extracurriculars in high school-- my time at R/GA showed me that often, both visually and for content, less is more.

The resume page in particular is a case in point. I had a graphical CV that rendered all of my experiences as visual blocks programmatically to a canvas. However, what I didn't realize was how overwhelming the entirety of this information would be, as visible in the screencap below, for someone who had never even met me.
Timeline 1.0
portfolio/muesugi/old-resume-timeline.png
Retaining the idea of the timeline and graphical representation that I liked, I thought about what experiences truly defined me in genuine ways. This, as can be seen in the
/resume
new resume page
, resulted in a more curated and meaningful graphical experience.
Timeline 2.0
portfolio/muesugi/new-timeline.png

projects.title: Brown WebServices IBES Globe

projects.title: String - Strung
projects.subtitle: a Girls Who Code summer project for crocheters
projects.description: Created as my final project for the Girls Who Code program in the span of under a week, the 'String' web tool allows users to enter a written crochet pattern and see a visual approximation (using Raphael.js) of the intended product to catch mistakes before publishing patterns. The 2.0 site, Strung, is pictured here.

children.text: As a crocheter myself, this project started because I found that written crochet patterns and code were quite similar. Not many people are involved in both worlds, so very few, if any, tools exist to help pattern designers and crocheters.

After my last week in the Girls Who Code program, my eigth official week learning to code, I had a rough prototype featuring a live editor that could responsive graphical representations of basic written crochet patterns.
portfolio/string-strung/string.png
Three years later, I decided to revisit the program-- now that I at least knew code style was a thing-- to create a more reliable, accurate, and stable tool.
I decided to create a 3D, navigable visualization application using THREE.js for the project visualization (Visualizer)
